division.name: main

section.title: Introduction
section.name: intro
section.blockquote: IntAct is a protein interaction database and analysis system. It provides a query interface and modules to analyse interaction data. This manual describes the IntAct data structure and the components of the IntAct system.

section.title: Main objects
section.name: mainObject
section.blockquote:
IntAct has the following main objects:
Experiment
Interaction
Interactor
Example (simplified): Representation of the Interleukin 2 receptor binding: One interaction object represents the complex of the alpha, beta, and gamma chains which form the receptor. This interaction object is the used in the second interaction object, in which the binding of Interleukin 2 to the receptor is represented. Both Interaction objects are linked to an experiment, in which the Interaction has been determined.
The following section describes the main objects in detail.

section.title: Experiment
section.name: Experiment
section.blockquote:
An Experiment object describes an experiment which has been performed to generate one or more interactions. It indicates the conditions in which the experiment has been performed. The description broadly classifies the experiment, it does not aim at providing all the necessary data to repeat the experiment. The attributes of the Experiment are the
BioSource The biological system in which the interaction took place in the experiment. identificationMethod The experimental method by which the molecules participating in the interaction have been detected.
Example: Mass spectrometry. interactionMethod The experimental method by which the interaction has been detected.
Example: yeast two hybrid.
Each Experiment provides a list of one or more Interactions which have been determined by this Experiment. One Experiment might contain a single Interaction, or many hundreds for large scale experiments.

section.title: Interaction
section.name: Interaction
section.blockquote:
The Interaction object describes the interaction of two or more Interactors (proteins). As the number of Interactors in an Interaction is not limited, an Interaction can describe both binary interactions, which are the result of for example yeast two hybrid experiments, and interactions with more than two Interactors, for example determined by "TAP" experiments. The attributes of an Interaction are
CvInteractionType A description of the type of interaction.
Example: association. kD The dissociation constant.

section.title: Interactor
section.name: Interactor
section.blockquote:
A molecule or complex participating in an Interaction. The only direct attribute of an Interactor is
BioSource The biological system in which the interactor normally is found. For a human protein, the BioSource would be "Human", even if it has been expressed in E.coli in a particular experiment.
If the Interactor is a Protein, it additionally has the attributes
sequence The amino acid sequence of the protein. crc64 The CRC64 checksum for the amino acid sequence. This checksum is used to quickly detect if the amino acid sequence has changed, for example during an update process. It is also used to check if the amino acid sequence has potentially been corrupted.
The algorithm to compute the CRC64 is described in the ISO 3309 standard. The generator polynomial is x64 + x4 + x3 + x + 1.
Reference: Press W.H., Flannery B.P., Teukolsky S.A. and Vetterling W.T. "Numerical recipes in C", 2nd ed., pp896-902, Cambridge University Press (1993). (See http://www.ulib.org/webRoot/Books/Numerical_Recipes/bookcpdf/c20-3.pdf) It should be noted that while, in theory, two different sequences could have the same CRC64 value, the likelihood that this would happen is extremely low.
An Interactor describes an "abstract" form of e.g. a protein, similar to a description in a protein sequence database. One protein can participate in many interactions. To describe the specific conditions in which an Interactor participates in an Interaction, the following additional attributes are used:
stoichiometry The number of units of this interactor which participate in the interaction. The default is one. expressedIn A BioSource object which describes the biological system in which the protein has been expressed.
Example: If a human protein has been expresed in E.coli, expressedIn would refer to E.coli. Role The role of the Interactor in the Interaction. In a yeast two hybrid experiment, each Interaction would usually have an Interactor which has the role "bait" and another one which has the role "prey".
An Interactor is normally a protein. However, to model hierarchical assemblies of complexes from subcomplexes, an Interactor can also be an Interaction.
Example: To model a receptor-ligand interaction, the receptor could be modeled by an interaction which describes the composition of the receptor from its component proteins. Then, in another Interaction, the association of receptor and ligand would be described. See the IL-2 example.

section.title: Auxiliary objects
section.name: AuxiliaryObjects
section.blockquote: The following objects are auxiliary objects, often used in several different main classes.

section.title: BioSource
section.name: BioSource
section.blockquote:
The BioSource object describes a biological system, usually a species. The attributes of a BioSource are
taxId The NCBI tax id, see the NCBI taxonomy server or the NEWT taxonomy server. shortLabel The shortLabel is the Swiss-Prot OS code, where available. fullName The full name is the scientific name of the species.

section.title: CvObject
section.name: CvObject
section.blockquote: IntAct makes intensive use of controlled vocabularies. Where possible, data attributes are controlled vocabularies, the terms are selected from a defined list instead of being free text. For each attribute which is selected from a controlled vocabulary, a specific CvXXXXX class exists, for example CvInteractionType. Each term in a controlled vocabulary has a definition, usually has crossreferences, and may have additional comments.

section.title: ac
section.name: BasicObject.ac
section.blockquote:
The accession number. This is a unique, stable identifier for an object. The same accession number will always be assiciated with the same object. To reference IntAct objects from outside, accession numbers should be used. The format of the accession number is one or more uppercase letters, followed by a dash, followed by a number.
In regular expression syntax: [A-Z]\-[0-9]+.
Example: EBI-15

section.title: shortLabel
section.name: AnnotatedObject.shortLabel
section.blockquote:
The short label is a short, concise name to identify an object. Short labels for proteins are usually gene names, short labels for experiments are usually the names of the first author of the publication. Short labels will normally be stable, but they may change, e.g. when the gene name of a protein is changed by the relevant nomenclature body, e.g. HUGO. Short labels are not guaranteed to be unique, e.g. if two proteins have the same primary gene name. They are guaranteed to be unique for controlled vocabulary terms within each controlled vocabulary.
Example: GOT2.

section.title: fullName
section.name: AnnotatedObject.fullName
section.blockquote:
The full name of the object.
Example: Aspartate aminotransferase.

section.title: Annotation
section.name: AnnotatedObject.Annotation
section.blockquote: Each object may have one or more annotations associated with it. Each annotation has a topic, which broadly classifies the annotation, and the annotation text.

section.title: created
section.name: BasicObject.created
section.blockquote: The date the object has been created.

section.title: updated
section.name: BasicObject.updated
section.blockquote: The date the object has been updated last.

Here comes the IntAct application documentation.
The search application currently allows a text-based search by entering a text string into the search text box. It is possible to obtain information on experiments, protein interactions and the proteins themselves, with various views used to display the data. Intact uses the concept of short label which is intended to provide a way of 'more memorable identification' compared to a standard Accession Number (AC), although searches by AC are obviously allowed. For example a particular Experiment may have an AC of EBI-14, but its short label is 'gavin' indicating a more meaningful reference to the physical experiment which the entry represents. Basic points on usage:
Wildcard searching is supported - for example matches will be retrieved for strings such as EBI*, *BI-14, E*4, etc etc.
upper or lower case strings are acceptable and will be matched if they exist
currently searches progress in a certain order: proteins, then interactions, then experiments. At a lower level, specific attributes are searched by AC, short label, Xref primary ID and finally full name. This algorithm may change as the intact project matures.
Note that whilst CvObject details can be displayed via the click of a link, currently it is not possible to search for CvObjects via the text box search entry point.

Searching for interactions, proteins or experiments typically results in the same view - a table detailing all the interactions for a particular experiment, with the short labels listed of the proteins involved in the interactions. An example result screen is shown below:
An example result view from clicking on a Protein link is shown below:
If for example in the above screen you click on 'SPTR', this will display the controlled vocabulary information for the database identified with a short label of 'SPTR'. The screen looks like this:
Protein short labels are links you can click to get a view of the protein details. Also each protein short label has a term in brackets (eg '[p]') which denotes the role that the protein plays in the interaction. These terms have tooltips associated with them to display the role name, and also the term is a clickable link from which you can view the full details of the controlled vocabulary term which presents the controlled vocabulary information for that term (eg the details held to define the meaning of the term 'bait').
Since the items displayed for a search result include many items not actually queried for, the items that matched the oringinal search string are highlighted in bold italic - there is even a helpful little message at the top of the results page to remind you of this. Specifically the *short labels* of the matching items are highlighted, since these are always displayed in every view.
Where a protein (for example) might actually occur more than once in an experiment, the display is rationalised to avoid multiple presentations of the same experiment - therefore all occurrences within an experiment are gathered together into one experiment view.
At the bottom of the page are a number of buttons:
a button to view the full details of what is on the results page (this expands all the information currently on the page, apart from the controlled vocabulary details);
a reset button to uncheck any textboxes;
a graph button to display a graph of any selected proteins, which can be chosen by clicking the appropriate checkboxes.

The application to edit IntAct database is only available for users with the write access to it. Hence, Editor application is not available to public access.
The editor is a web based tool to edit IntAct database. Presently, it supports following IntAct objects: CvTopic, CvCellCycle, CvDatabase, CvTissue, CvModificationType, CvCellType, Protein, CvComponentRole, CvFeatureType, CvCompartment, CvProductRole, CvFeatureIdentification, CvInteraction, BioSource, NucleicAcid, CvAliasType, SmallMolecule, CvProteinForm, CvInteractionType, Experiment, Complex, CvReferenceQualifier, CvXrefQualifier, CvEvidenceType, CvIdentification, Interaction, CvDevelopmentalStage
Note: Any IntAct type name beginning with Cv is referred to as Cv type from here onwards.
The URL to access the editor is dependent upon the server where the editor is installed. The general format to access the editor takes the form of:
http://server/intact/editor, where the server part may contain the port depending upon the configuration of the web server.
To use the editor, you must have a valid account to access the Intact database. The user is presented with a login screen as shown below:
Failure to login with a valid account results in the following error display:
This list defines the types available for edit. Before proceeding with any action (search or create), you must select an appropriate type first.
The IntAct type list defaults to the first item (e.g., BioSource) if a type wasn't selected.
The user must select the type to edit from the drop down list (defaults to the first item in the list if none specified).
The input field under the drop down list accepts the search criteria. The search is performed first on accession number (ac), and then on short label, primary id and full name respectively. So, it is faster to search by an accession number than by a short label.
You can accept the default search value (*) by simply clicking on the search button. This may take some time depending on the database size as it retrieves all records for given IntAct type. However, you can also use more restrictive filtering such as EBI-3* to restrieve a subset of records. The following screen provides an example to this.
An appropriate message is displayed if a search fails to find any matching records. Click on the AC link to edit individual entry. Alternatively, you can enter the short label directly in the search box and it will take you to the edit screen if a matching record wasn't found for given short label and type as shown below.
The search is carried out against the value in the drop down list. So, ensure that you correctly select the type first before the search.
The create button creates a record for the selected IntAct type. As with the search, it is important to select the appropriate type before clicking on the create button. The following screen shows the result of creating a new CvDatabase record.
The current edit type is appended to the main heading (CvDatabase) as shown above. All the drop down list items (topic, database and reference qualifier) are shown as short labels. Except for the short label, all other fields are optional. The user must select 'Save' button to validate the short label. All short labels should be one to twenty characters from the character set blank, 0..9, a-z, : (colon) and -(dash). A dialog box similar to the following will appear for a failure to adhere to this syntax.
Submitting the form without entering a syntaxically invalid short label results in a server side validation. The error response from the server is shown under the short label as shown below.
Although both validations are similar in nature, they serve two different purposes. The first validation is performed on the client side (browser) and hence faster of the two. However, the browser must be enabled to accept Javascript for it to work (no dialog window if Javascript is not enabled). This is the preferred validation as it saves extra step in communication with the server. Alternatively, the other validation is not dependent on Javascript and hence guranteed to work on any browser. However, it is slow since it involves a round trip to the server.
For a short label to be valid it must be syntaxically correct and unique (i.e, no simlar label for the current edit type exists in the database). All the existing short lables for the current edit types are shown along with an error message for a non unique short label entry.
Annotations are added by clicking on the Add button in the Annotation section. Associated with each Annotation is a topic which is one of CvTopics available in the database. An error message is displayed when trying to add an annotation without selecting an appropriate type from the drop down lists.
The editing an annotation is similar to adding a new Annotation except for topic and description are already set to their existing values. The screen snapshot given below shows two annotations with one in the editing mode.
Similar to Annotations, Crossreferences are added by clicking on the Add button in the Crossreference section. The database drop list consists of short labels for CvDatbase itsm from the IntAct database and the reference qualifier consists of short labels for CvXrefQualifier.
As with annotations, the values from drop down lists must be selected prior to adding a crossreference. Editing an existing Crossreference similar to adding a new one except for existing values are shown instead of empty values.
Any changes to the form are not saved until the form is submitted. So for a new IntAct type, a record is created on the database until the Submit button is clicked and the server reports no errors.
Editing an existing record is similar to the above except the form is populated with existing data. As shown below, the short label and full name already have their existing values.
Since Cv editor layout is common to all other editors, only the differences are shown for other editors.

To add a Protein, you must search for existing Proteins first by provide appropriate values for search fields. Only the most specific value is taken into consideration if multiple values are provided for search. What browsers Editor supports?
It has been tested using Mozilla (1.4a), Explorer (6.0) and Konqueror (2.1.1 or above). With the Konqueror it has been noted that pop up windows do not get the focus (need to bring them manually). Also, the footer is almost at the top when a page does not contain much information.
Do I need a JRE installed to run the Editor?
No, you don't need Java Runtime to run the Editor as it is designed to run on thin clients (see the next question about JavaScript).
Do I need JavaScript to run the Editor?
No but it helps a lot. For example, some validations such as short label syntax are faster as they are peformed via JavaScript. Also, the links to pop up windows wouldn't work when JavaScript is not enabled. However, the overall functionality of the Editor shouldn't be affected if JavaScript is not enabled.
Do I need to logout when I am finished?
There is no need to logout because your session will timeout if it has been inactive for 30 or more minutes. However, by explicitly logging out you are releasing the resources (good thing to do). So, we recommend explicit logouts.
Can I connect to my last session when my session expires?
No. Once your session expires you need to login again and this in turn will start a new session.
I get an error stack trace for some IntAct types.
Not to worry because these types are not implemented yet. This exception shouldn't appear at all once we have implemented all the IntAct types.
Sometimes I get an error when Enter key is pressed for a search string in the sidebar.
This behaviour was observed with Explorer and Konqueror but not with Mozilla. The simple solution is to click on Search button instead.
After entering 'abc' as a short label, I pressed Save and it accepted 'abc' as the short label. Now I entered 'ab%' and the form is submitted without any complaints. I thought 'ab%' is an invalid short label and the expected error message didn't appear. What is happening?
As far as the system is concerned it remembers the value associated with the last 'Save' action. Since you pressed 'Save' after 'abc' but not after 'ab%', it has already assigned 'abc' as the short label. In a nut shell, it is not even aware of 'ab%' because it hasn't seen it.
It hangs for a tax id in BioSource editor.
Either Newt server is not accessible or down. There is no way to get around this problem; you need to access the Newt server to do the auto-completion.
Not allowed to save an experiment as it fails with validation errors for drop down lists.
Those drop down lists must contain at least a single item for an Experiment to save. Ensure that host organism, interaction detection and participant detection have at least one value in each one of them. If not then use the editor to create values for these (BioSource, CvInteraction and CvIndetification) and return to the Experiment editor. In summary, if you are caught in this situation you need to leave the Experiment editor, create proper entries and then return to it later.
The parameter to search for Proteins given as short label is ignored when a value is provided for IntactAc in the Interaction editor.
By default, IntAct AC is the most specific and it is followed by SP AC and finally the short label. Given two values for short label and IntAct AC, the latter is always given the priority.
Is there a way to save or delete all Proteins in one single click?
Not at the moment. We may add this behaviour later.
HierarchView is a web based application which aims to give the user some basic features in order to visualize the data contained in his IntAct node.
This includes :
Query interface: to select the set of Interactor from which the interaction network is built,
Visualising an interaction network as a two dimensional graph,
Visualisation of a protein's context (using Search application),
Performing action by clicking on a protein of the displayed network,
Center the view,
Extend the view,
Displaying GO terms of all proteins from which the interaction network is built,
Displaying the GO hierarchy of a selected GO term
Highlighting all proteins annotated by a specific GO term (selected by the user)
The application to visualize protein interaction network is available if you can fulfill the software dependencies requirement such as Tulip which allows to perform the graphical rendering. However, if those dependencies are sorted out, the user just need a read access to the database to use it.
The graphical user interface is integrates:
a sidebar
the basic sidebar:
Some components of the sidebar are always visible whatever the state of the application.
This includes:
on the top, the query interface.
on the bottom, a set of IntAct related link.
the advanced sidebar: After loading a first interaction network, more features are available in the sidebar :
below the query interface, the Graph menu which allows to expand and contract the current interaction network,
above the link section, the mouse-click behaviour section which allows the user to switch the mouse-click behaviour either to center the view or add a new network.
a content frame
PPIN header: it specifies from which protein(s) is built the current interaction network as well as the number of nodes and edges. If needed, the selected GO term used for the highlightis displayed.
PPIN content: a clickable image representing the requested interaction network.
highlight top: a list of GO terms related to the set of proteins from which the current interaction network has been generated.
highlight bottom: After selecting one of the GO term displayed in the top right frame, the related GO hierarchy is displayed, allowing the user to perform a highlight by selecting on the GO term of the hierarchy.

It is a graphical way of representing an protein protein interaction network as a two dimensional graph structure. Within that graph, the nodes represent proteins and the edges a physical interaction.
The entry point of an interaction network is an Interactor (either Protein or Interaction) around which we will look for all Interactors within a specified threshold called depth. A depth 1 would be all direct Interactor of the selected protein.
Type in the Interactor form either a protein short label or accession number and click the search button to display the related interaction network. You are free to type a comma separated list of proteins in order to display all of them in one go.
The visualization systems shows all specified proteins with a bold font. As soon as the interaction network is displayed, the user interface is changing slightly to offer more interactivity.
When querying IntAct to display an interaction network, if the query is ambiguous (e.g. the query snu* could describes several proteins such as snu66, snu13...), you will be automatically forwarded to the search application where you will be able to select the targeted protein(s).
When adding a interaction network, a new one is generated according to the user's wishes and then fusionned to the current one to display them alltogether.
There is two ways of doing it:
Type in the Interactor form either a protein short label or AC and click the add button. You are free to type a comma separated list of protein in order to display all of them in one go.
If the protein of interrest is available in the current interaction network, you can switch the mouse-click (sidebar) behaviour to add a network then click on the wanted protein.
In order to navigate in the interaction network, you can decide to change the current central protein. To do so, switch the mouse-click (sidebar) behaviour to center the view, then, click on the wanted protein. The current interaction network will be reloaded as the interaction network of the selected protein.
Bear in mind that it would have had the same effect to type the short label or accession number of the protein in the Interactor form and clicked on the search button.
In order to improve the readability and the loading time, the default depth of an interaction network has been set relatively low. Nevertheless you can increase that parameter in order to expand the current interaction network by clicking the expand button in the sidebar. Bear in mind that there is a minimum and maximum depth, this implies the expand (contract) button to disapear when the maximum (minimum) depth is reached.
After loading an interaction network, a list of GO terms specific to the set of selected proteins is displayed in the top right frame of hierarchView. By clicking on one of them, the related GO hierarchy appears in the bottom right frame (powered by QuickGo). If a single GO term is found, the hierarchy is displayed automaticaly. Now You can select one of the displayed GO term of the hierarchy in order to highlight in the interaction network all proteins annotated with that GO term in IntAct. These proteins will appear with a different color label.
In the displayed hierarchy, the lower GO term is the more specific, and the higher you go, the most generic the GO terms become. Bear in mind that when selecting a GO term in the displayed hierarchy the highlight is done with a set of GO terms including the selected one and all its children (i.e. until the most specific).
